document.docAuthor: Paul, Nilotpol, Hazra, Niladri & Mazumdar, Abhijit
document.docTitle: Monopelopia mongpuense Paul, Hazra & Mazumdar, 2014, sp. n.
document.masterDocTitle: Monopelopia mongpuense sp. n., a phytotelmata midge from sub – Himalayan region of India (Diptera: Chironomidae: Tanypodinae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Monopelopia mongpuense sp. n., a phytotelmata midge from sub – Himalayan region of India (Diptera: Chironomidae: Tanypodinae)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type material.
Holotype adult male ( Type no. B.U. Ent. 249 ), West Bengal: Darjeeling, Mongpu ( 26 º 94 ́N, 88 º 35 E),
08.VI. 2012
, Coll. N. Paul. Paratypes
3 male
adults and
2 female
adults with associated pupae and larvae (reared), same data as holotype .

Diagnostic Characters . Adult male of the new species may be separated from other members of the genus by scattered pigment granules on tergites and gonocoxite, Wing length 1.74–2.22 mm , short palpomere II with several roughly biserial pale long setae, hind tibial comb with 8 setae and hind tarsomere without pseudospur. Adult female of the new species may be separated from other female member of the genus by almost rounded seminal capsules, arch shaped notum and ratio SCa/No 0.54–0.57 . Pupa is distinct in having a large plastron plate occupying 35–41 horn length, ThR 4.60–5.12 , sub equal and simple Dc 1 and Dc 2 , D 4 setae on tergites IV–VI placed more mid–distally, 4 LS setae on segment VII, 5 LS setae on segment VII and equal length of Genital sac and Anal lobe. The larvae are distinctive by brick–red spots on lateral side of each segment, cephalic index 0.53–0.56 , dark brown and rounded small claw on posterior parapod with 3 inner teeth and VP of ventral cephalic head capsule small.
Etymology . The species has been named after the small hamlet Mongpu, near Darjeeling town where it was collected. Literally, ‘Mongpu’ means transition to immortality (in Buddhism).

Description. Male adult (n = 4 , except when otherwise stated)
Figs. 1–8
Coloration. Pale yellow with scattered brownish pigment spots on tergites. Abdomen pale yellow and vittae pale brown.
Total length 1.95–2.2 mm ; wing length 0.92–1.15 mm ; total length/wing length 1.74–2.39 ; wing length/length of profemur 2.35–2.81 .

Wing (
Fig. 4
). Covered with macrotrichia becoming more dense towards distal gradually and without any maculation. Wing width 330–360 Μm. R 2 present but not forked apically and faint towards costa. C
1010–1025
Μm long, Sc 525–532 Μm long, R 1 425–435 Μm long, R 4 + 5 565–578 Μm long, M 1 + 2 754–772 Μm long. VR 0.84–0.87 ; squama with 16–18 setae; brachiolum with 2 setae, two weak campaniform sensilla present.
Length and proportion of leg segments (n = 3 ) as in table 1 A & 1 B.

subSubSection.paragraph: Abdomen. Sternite pale yellow in color. Tergite pale yellow in color with few brown pigmented spot.

Female adult (n = 2 , expect when otherwise stated)
Fig. 9
Coloration. Usual like male with more brown appearance.
Similar to male with usual sex difference except following:
Total length 1.18–1.24 mm , wing length 0.98–1.04 mm , AR 4.54–4.61 , antenna with 11 flagellomeres.
Pupa (n = 5 , except when otherwise stated) Figs. 10–14
Length of exuviae 2.63–2.77 mm , living pupa pale yellow in colour, exuviae transparent with distal light brown shed on each segment. Female pupal exuviae more brown.

Larva (n = 3 , except otherwise stated)
Figs. 15–22
Total length 2.81–3.15 mm . Cephalic index 0.53–0.58 ,
Living larvae pale yellow in colour, two brick–red coloured spots on each side of tergite.

sp. n.

sp.n. , pupa. 10: thoracic horn, 11: abdominal segments ventral (left side) & dorsal (right side), 12: shagreen on segment II, 13: shagreen on segment IV, 14: closer view of segment IV ventral (left side) & dorsal (right side).

FIGURES 15–22.
Monopelopia mongpuense
sp. n.
, larva. 15: apex of antenna, 16: mandible, 17: maxillary palp, 18: mentum & M appendages, 19: ligula & paraligula, 20: pecten hypopharyngis, 21: head capsule with position of cephalic setae & sensory pore – left ventral aspect & right dorsal aspect, 22: claws of posterior parapods.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Ligula (
Fig. 19
). 57–80 Μm long, inner and middle tooth 10–12 Μm long, apical half of tooth deeply brown; paraligula (
Fig. 19
). 27–36 Μm long, inner point 9–10 Μm and outer point 13–15 Μm long. It/
O 0.70
–0.78; Mt/
O 0.82
–0.90.

Cephalic chaetotaxy as in figure 21 . Dorsal seta: S 7 and S 8 closely placed each other and along with S 5 formed a roughly 90 º angle. Ventral seta: S 9 , S 10 , VP and SSm producing a roughly a rhombus shape; VP small, not large like other species.
